entry.title: RTR Cutover Tasks and Data Validations during Go-Live
entry.content:
RTR Cutover Tasks and Data Validations during Go-Live:

(GenAI Assisted Content created based on Personal Experience)

 

  • Introduction of RTR Overall Cutover Task:

During a Go-Live Cutover for SAP Finance (FI), data validation is a critical activity to ensure that all migrated and newly created financial data is accurate, complete, and ready for business operations in the new SAP system. Below is a summary of key data validation activities and best practices during Go-Live cutover in SAP Finance:

Key SAP Finance Data Validations During Go-Live Cutover

  1. Master Data Validation
  • General Ledger (GL) Accounts: Verify all GL accounts are created, with correct account types, descriptions, and assignments.
  • Vendor & Customer Master: Check all vendor/customer details (name, address, payment terms, bank details, recon accounts).
  • Asset Master: Confirm all assets are transferred with correct values, depreciation terms, asset class, cost center assignment.
  • Bank Master Data: Validate bank accounts, bank keys, and related information.
  1. Open Item Validation
  • AP/AR Open Items: Ensure all open items in Accounts Payable and Receivable are migrated correctly, with right document numbers, amounts, due dates, and assignments.
  • GL Open Items: Check open GL items are migrated and reconciled to legacy system balances.
  1. Balances Validation
  • GL Balances: Validate period-end and year-end closing balances for all GL accounts.
  • AP/AR Balances: Reconcile vendor/customer balances between SAP and legacy system.
  • Asset Balances: Confirm asset values and accumulated depreciation match legacy system.
  1. Transactional Data Validation
  • Journal Entries: Ensure all migrated journal entries are complete and accurate.
  • Documents Posting: Test posting new documents to ensure system configuration is correct.
  • Document Numbers: Verify document number ranges and sequences.
  1. Configuration & Controls Validation
  • Tax Codes: Validate correct tax codes, rates, and assignments.
  • Payment Terms & Methods: Check that payment terms and methods are correctly set up.
  • Reconciliation Accounts: Confirm recon accounts are correctly assigned to vendors/customers.
  • Posting Periods: Ensure correct posting periods are open/closed as per cutover plan.
  1. Reporting Validation
  • Run standard SAP FI reports (e.g., trial balance, balance sheet, vendor/customer balances, asset reports) and compare with legacy system reports.
  • Validate custom reports if applicable.
  1. User Acceptance Testing (UAT) & Approval
  • Users review and sign-off on sample data, balances, and reports.
  • Document approval and exception handling process.
  1. Interfaces & Integration Validation
  • Validate data flow to/from other modules (MM, SD, Asset Accounting) and external systems (bank interfaces, tax authorities).

Cutover Data Validation Checklist (Sample)

Validation Type

Activity

Responsible

GL Master Data

Check all GL accounts & attributes

FI Lead

Vendor Master Data

Verify vendor details & recon accounts

AP Team

Customer Master Data

Validate customer info & recon accounts

AR Team

AP Open Items

Reconcile open AP items

FI/AP Team

AR Open Items

Reconcile open AR items

FI/AR Team

GL Balances

Match closing balances with legacy system

FI Lead

Asset Balances

Confirm asset values and depreciation

Asset Team

Tax Codes

Verify tax code setup

FI Lead

Document Posting

Test postings in SAP

FI Team

Reporting

Run and validate SAP reports

FI Team

Best Practices

  • Plan for multiple rounds of validation: Ideally, run validations during mock cutovers before the actual go-live.
  • Document every validation step and result for audit and compliance.
  • Assign clear ownership for each validation activity.
  • Resolve all discrepancies before final cutover sign-off.
  • Communicate findings and actions to stakeholders regularly.

 

  • Loading Trial Balance in SAP During Cutover

Loading the Trial Balance into SAP during the cutover is a key activity to ensure that the opening balances in the new SAP system match those from the legacy system. This process usually involves uploading balances into General Ledger (GL) accounts as of the cutover date (e.g., opening balance at the start of the fiscal period).

Below is a step-by-step guideline for loading the Trial Balance into SAP FI:

  1. Preparation
  2. Extract Trial Balance from Legacy System
  • Export the final, reconciled trial balance as of the cutover date (usually period end).
  • Ensure balances are mapped to SAP GL accounts.
  1. Data Mapping
  • Map legacy GL accounts to SAP GL account numbers.
  • Ensure company codes, profit centers, cost centers, and other dimensions are mapped.
  1. File Preparation
  • Prepare the data for upload in a required format (usually Excel or CSV).
  • Typical fields: Company Code, Fiscal Year, Period, GL Account, Amount, Debit/Credit indicator, Profit Center, Cost Center (if applicable).
  1. Loading Methods in SAP

You can use several methods to upload Trial Balance data into SAP:

  1. Direct Entry via Transaction Code F-02 (Manual Entry)
  • Use T-code F-02 (Enter GL Account Posting).
  • Enter each GL account opening balance as a line item.
  • This is feasible only for small trial balances.

**B. Batch Input / LSMW (Legacy System Migration Workbench)

  • Use LSMW or Batch Input to mass upload data.
  • Steps:
    1. Create an LSMW project for GL postings (usually using object: 0100, method: 0000, program: RFBIBL00).
    2. Prepare the data file in the format required by the program.
    3. Upload and process the file, generating batch input sessions.
    4. Run the batch input session to post documents.

**C. SAP Standard Program: RFBIBL00 (Batch Input for Accounting Documents)

  • This is a popular method for mass upload.
  • Download the sample file template for RFBIBL00 from SAP.
  • Populate your trial balance data.
  • Upload the file using transaction SM35 (Batch Input) or via LSMW.

**D. SAP S/4HANA Migration Cockpit

  • For S/4HANA systems, use the Migration Cockpit to upload opening balances.
  • Use the "FI - GL Account Balances" migration object.
  1. Posting to SAP
  • The upload process typically posts to a special document type (e.g., â€˜SAâ€™) with a reference indicating â€˜Opening Balanceâ€™.
  • Postings are made to the first open period in SAP (e.g., period 1 of the fiscal year).
  1. Validation and Reconciliation

After loading:

  • Run SAP reports (e.g., F.01 â€“ Financial Statement, S_ALR_87012277 â€“ GL Account Balances) to verify balances.
  • Reconcile SAP Trial Balance with the legacy trial balance.
  • Investigate and resolve any discrepancies.
  1. Documentation
  • Document the process, mappings, and validations.
  • Keep audit trails of uploaded files, posting documents, and reconciliation results.

Sample Data File Format (for RFBIBL00 or LSMW)

Company Code

Fiscal Year

Period

GL Account

Amount

D/C Indicator

Text

Profit Center

Cost Center

1000

2025

01

400000

150,000

D

Opening Bal.

1100

2100

1000

2025

01

200000

150,000

C

Opening Bal.

1200

2200

Tips and Best Practices

  • Post only opening balances, not individual transactions.
  • Ensure all balances are posted for the correct fiscal period and company code.
  • Review posting logs and error reports after the upload.
  • Get business and finance team sign-off after reconciliation.
  • Keep documentation for audit and compliance.

 

 

  • Open GR or IR wrt Purchase Orders Load:

Loading Open GR (Goods Receipt) and Open IR (Invoice Receipt) with reference to purchase orders from the legacy system during SAP cutover is an essential step to ensure the transition to SAP is seamless and your procurement processes remain accurate.

Below is a practical, step-by-step guide to help you understand and execute this process:

How to Load Open GR and Open IR During Cutover in SAP

  1. What Are Open GR and Open IR?
  • Open GR: Goods have been received against a PO in legacy, but the invoice is not yet posted.
  • Open IR: Invoice has been received against a PO, but the goods have not yet been received, or sometimes the invoice is posted but payment not yet made.
  • Both must be migrated to SAP to reflect correct PO status, inventory, and liabilities.
  1. Data Preparation
  2. Extract Data from Legacy System
  • List all open POs with pending GRs (where goods have been received but invoice not posted) and open IRs (where invoice received but goods not yet received or invoice posted but payment not made).
  • Capture key details: PO number, item, quantity, value, vendor, material, plant, etc.
  1. Map Legacy Data to SAP Structure
  • Map legacy PO numbers to SAP PO numbers (if numbers change).
  • Ensure material, plant, vendor codes match SAP master data.
  1. Loading Open GR (Goods Receipt) in SAP
  2. Using Transaction MB01/MIGO with Movement Type 101 (Goods Receipt for PO)
  1. Create Goods Receipt (GR):
    • Transaction: MIGO (or MB01 in ECC)
    • Reference: Purchase Order
    • Movement Type: 101
    • Enter quantity and value as per open GR in legacy.
    • Post the GR document.
  2. Repeat for all open GRs.
    • Ensure the posting date matches the legacy GR date (if possible).
  3. Result:
    • Inventory updated in SAP.
    • PO history updated with GR.
    • Accounting entries posted.
  1. Mass Upload Method
  • For many open GRs, use LSMW or BAPI_GOODSMVT_CREATE for automated upload.
  1. Loading Open IR (Invoice Receipt) in SAP
  2. Using Transaction MIRO (Enter Incoming Invoice)
  1. Create Invoice Receipt (IR):
    • Transaction: MIRO
    • Reference: Purchase Order
    • Enter invoice number, quantity, value, vendor, and other relevant details.
    • Post the IR document.
  2. Repeat for all open IRs.
    • Make sure to use correct document/invoice dates.
  3. Result:
    • Vendor liability updated in SAP.
    • PO history updated with IR.
    • Accounting entries posted.
  1. Mass Upload Method
  • For large volumes, use LSMW or BAPI_INCOMINGINVOICE_CREATE for automated upload.
  1. Recommendations & Best Practices
  • Sequence: Always upload open GRs before open IRs to maintain correct PO history and avoid system errors.
  • Reconciliation: After upload, reconcile PO histories, inventory, and vendor liabilities in SAP with legacy balances.
  • Document Mapping: Retain references to legacy document numbers for traceability.
  • Testing: Try the process in a quality/test system before production cutover.
  • Audit Trail: Document all uploads and reconciliations for audit purposes.
  1. Sample Data Structure for Upload

Open GR (MIGO/MB01):

PO Number

PO Item

Material

Plant

Quantity

Value

Posting Date

450000123

10

MAT001

1000

50

5,000

2025-09-25

Open IR (MIRO):

PO Number

PO Item

Invoice No

Vendor

Quantity

Value

Invoice Date

450000123

10

INV-789

VEND01

50

5,000

2025-09-25

Summary Table

Activity

Transaction

Movement Type

Reference

Automation Option

Open GR

MIGO/MB01

101

PO

LSMW, BAPI_GOODSMVT_CREATE

Open IR

MIRO

N/A

PO

LSMW, BAPI_INCOMINGINVOICE_CREATE

 

  • Open Deliveries with respect to Sales Orders:

Loading Open Deliveries with respect to Sales Orders during SAP cutover is crucial to ensure your order fulfillment and billing processes continue seamlessly after go-live.

Below is a practical, step-by-step guide for loading open deliveries in SAP SD during cutover:

How to Load Open Deliveries with respect to Sales Orders During Cutover

  1. Understand the Business Scenario
  • Open Deliveries = Deliveries created in the legacy system for sales orders, but goods issue (GI) has not yet been posted, or billing not yet done.
  • You need to recreate these deliveries in SAP so you can post GI and invoice them after go-live, reflecting the correct order status and inventory position.
  1. Data Preparation
  2. Extract Data from Legacy System
  • List all open deliveries and their corresponding sales orders.
  • Key details: Sales order number, item, delivery number, delivery quantity, material, plant, shipping point, delivery date, customer, etc.
  1. Map Data to SAP Structure
  • Ensure legacy sales orders, materials, customers, shipping points, and plants are mapped to SAP master data.
  • If delivery numbers change, maintain legacy reference for audit.
  1. Loading Open Deliveries in SAP
  2. Manual Creation (For Small Volumes)
  1. Create Delivery:
    • Transaction: VL01N (Create Outbound Delivery with Order Reference)
    • Enter the sales order number and shipping point.
    • Enter delivery quantity and other relevant details.
    • Save the delivery.
  2. Repeat for each open delivery.
  1. Mass Upload (For Large Volumes)
  • Use LSMW (Legacy System Migration Workbench), BAPI_OUTB_DELIVERY_CREATE_SLS, or custom ABAP programs to automate delivery creation.

LSMW Approach:

  • Object: Standard Batch/Direct Input for Deliveries or use BAPI.
  • Prepare upload file with all required fields: sales order, item, quantity, shipping point, delivery date, etc.

BAPI Approach:

  • Use BAPI_OUTB_DELIVERY_CREATE_SLS to create outbound deliveries programmatically.
  1. Post Cutover Activities
  • After deliveries are loaded, you can process further actions:
    • Goods Issue Posting: Transaction VL02N (Change Outbound Delivery) to post GI when the goods are shipped.
    • Billing: After GI, process invoice (VF01).
  1. Validation and Reconciliation
  • Reconcile open deliveries in SAP with the legacy system list.
  • Check delivery status, quantities, and dates.
  • Ensure no duplicate or missing deliveries.
  • Validate that the inventory position is correct.
  1. Best Practices
  • Sequence: Ensure open sales orders are loaded before deliveries.
  • Testing: Perform the process in a test system before production cutover.
  • Audit Trail: Retain legacy delivery numbers for reference in custom fields or SAP texts.
  • Communication: Coordinate with warehouse/logistics and order management teams.

Sample Upload Data Structure

Sales Order

Order Item

Delivery Qty

Material

Plant

Shipping Point

Delivery Date

Customer

500000123

10

100

MAT001

1100

SH01

2025-09-25

100001

Summary Table

Activity

Transaction / Method

Reference

Automation Option

Open Delivery Creation

VL01N / LSMW / BAPI

Sales Order

LSMW, BAPI_OUTB_DELIVERY_CREATE_SLS

Goods Issue Posting

VL02N

Outbound Delivery

 

Invoice Creation

VF01

Outbound Delivery

 

 

  • Inventory GL Balance Load Method:

Loading Inventory GL balances during SAP cutover is a critical step that must be handled carefully to ensure both financial accuracy and proper integration with the Materials Management (MM) module. Below is a clear, step-by-step guide on how to load Inventory GL balances during cutover in SAP:

  1. Understand the Business Scenario
  • Inventory balances represent the value of stock on hand as per your legacy system.
  • In SAP, inventory values should match both the FI GL balances and the MM stock quantities.
  1. Preparation
  2. Extract Inventory Balances from Legacy System
  • Obtain inventory account balances (GL) as of cutover date.
  • Obtain inventory quantities and values by material, plant, and storage location if using MM module.
  1. Data Mapping
  • Map legacy inventory GL accounts to SAP GL accounts.
  • Map materials, plants, storage locations if uploading to MM.
  1. Loading Methods
  2. If Using SAP FI Only (GL Level, No MM Integration)
  • Use LSMW or Batch Input (RFBIBL00) to post opening balances to inventory GL accounts.
  • This method only updates FI and does not create stock in MM.

Steps:

  1. Prepare upload file with company code, fiscal year, period, inventory GL account, amount, debit/credit indicator, text.
  2. Use LSMW or RFBIBL00 to upload as a normal GL posting (document type 'SA' or 'OB').
  3. Reconcile total inventory balance in SAP FI with legacy system.
  1. If Using SAP FI-MM Integration (Standard Approach)

Best Practice:
Always create initial stock in SAP MM (using transaction code MB1C or MIGO) so that both MM and FI are updated. This ensures proper valuation and future reconciliation.

Steps:

  1. Create Initial Stock (MM):
    • Use transaction MB1C or MIGO with movement type 561 ("Initial entry of stock balances").
    • Enter material number, quantity, plant, storage location, and value.
    • The system automatically posts inventory value to the inventory GL account via automatic account determination.
  2. Result:
    • MM stock quantities are created.
    • FI is updated with inventory balance in the correct GL account.
  3. Reconciliation:
    • Run inventory valuation reports (e.g., MB5B, MB52) to check MM stock.
    • Run FAGLB03 or FS10N to check GL balances.
    • Reconcile between MM and FI.
  1. Validation and Sign-Off
  • Compare SAP inventory balances (FI and MM) with legacy system.
  • Investigate and resolve any discrepancies.
  • Obtain sign-off from both Finance and Inventory teams.
  1. Documentation
  • Document process, mappings, posting documents, and reconciliation results for audit purposes.

Sample Upload File for MM Initial Stock (MB1C, Movement Type 561)

Material

Plant

Storage Location

Quantity

Value per Unit

Total Value

MAT001

1000

SLOC01

500

10

5,000

FI Posting Generated Automatically:

GL Account

Amount

D/C Indicator

Text

140000

5,000

D

Initial Stock

Tips & Best Practices

  • Always load stock via MM if you are using inventory management; do not post directly to inventory GL in FI for stock that should be managed in MM.
  • Check automatic account determination in SAP (transaction OBYC) to ensure postings go to correct inventory GL.
  • Test in a QA system before production cutover.
  • Ensure quantities and values match between MM and FI.

 

  • Running standard cost calculation after Inventory initial load with legacy Standard Price:

Running standard cost calculation before any logistics transactions or goods movements are posted during SAP Go-Live cutover is a vital step, especially for organizations implementing Standard Costing in SAP CO-PC (Product Costing) and MM.

Hereâ€™s a clear, step-by-step guideline for this process:

Why Run Standard Cost Calculation Before Logistics Transactions?

  • Ensures accurate inventory valuation: All incoming goods (stock) during initial postings and after go-live will be valued at the correct standard cost.
  • Prevents valuation inconsistencies: If goods movements (e.g., GR, GI) are posted before standard costs are set, inventory can be valued at zero or incorrect rates.
  • Enables proper cost control and profitability analysis.

Step-by-Step: Standard Cost Calculation During Cutover

  1. Pre-requisites
  • All relevant master data (materials, BOM, routings, work centers, cost centers, activity rates) are loaded and validated in SAP.
  • All costing variants, costing versions, and valuation strategies are set up.
  • No goods movements or logistics transactions have been posted yet.
  1. Standard Cost Estimate Run
  2. Run Cost Estimate for Materials
  • Transaction Code: CK11N (Create Material Cost Estimate)
  • Select the relevant materials/plants and run the cost estimate.
  • Review detailed cost components: raw materials, labor, overhead, etc.
  1. Mark the Cost Estimates
  • Transaction Code: CK24 (Mark and Release Cost Estimates)
  • Mark the cost estimates for the desired costing version and period.
  1. Release the Cost Estimates
  • Still in CK24, release the marked cost estimates.
  • This action updates the material master (accounting view) with the new standard price (field: Standard Price, typically field VPRS in S/4HANA, STPRS in ECC).
  1. Validation
  • Check material master data (MM03) to confirm standard price is updated.
  • Run relevant reports (e.g., CK13N â€“ Display Material Cost Estimate, CK40N â€“ Mass Processing of Cost Estimates).
  1. Proceed with Logistics Transactions
  • Only after standard cost estimates are released, begin posting goods receipts, initial stock uploads (MB1C/MIGO with movement type 561), or other logistics transactions.
  • This ensures all inventory postings are valued at the correct standard cost.

Best Practices

  • Do not post any goods movements before standard costs are released.
  • Reconcile and validate costing results before release.
  • Communicate clearly with business teams and cutover managers regarding the sequence.
  • Document all steps for compliance and audit.

Process Flow Summary

  1. Load master data (materials, BOMs, routings, etc.)
  2. Run standard cost estimates (CK11N/CK40N)
  3. Mark and release standard costs (CK24)
  4. Validate standard prices on material master
  5. Post initial stocks/goods movements (MB1C/MIGO)
  6. Continue with other logistics and financial transactions

entry.title: In SAP Public Cloud, there is an issue in sales order pricing.
entry.content: In Sap public cloud In sales order pricing, there is a manual condition type ZPR1 used for the base price. Currently, the system allows entering this condition type multiple times in the same line item. These multiple entries are added together in the pricing calculation, which can result in incorrect totals. For example, if ZPR1 is entered twice â€” once for â‚¹100 and again for â‚¹300 â€” the system calculates a total of â‚¹400, which is incorrect. but we need it only allowing one time.

entry.title: Re: PRD: Unable to convert UTC timezone to specific Timezone
entry.content:
@Julie_Davis_Wyn here is a screen shot of where you need to add it :

rf.preffered_timezone you can take with the following join. It will find the preferred time zone of report executor(admins):

left Join PA_USER_PREFERENCE rf --Preference TimeZone per user Table
on rf.user_id=(select top 1 owner from PA_REPORT_JOB ORDER BY last_update_timestamp DESC) and rf.USER_TYPE='A'

Because when you run query in PRD or SQL workbench it always read the regional settings of your computer and try to show the data in timezone from our windows setting.

entry.title: Dynamic Pictures (Headers/Footers) on Document Generation Template (SF Employee Central)
entry.content:
Dear All,

I recently worked on a useâ€case in Employee Centralâ€™s document generation tool where the client needed dynamic headers, footers, and signatures to vary based on the legal entity. The twist? The documents must remain in the same format across entities.

After researching blogs, troubleshooting, and consulting an SAP expert, I landed on a solution that allows the system to automatically insert the correct logo or image when an employee generates a document. Below is how it works:(After 2505 Release)

SOLUTION:

Step 1: Insert all your Images into a single Document Template (For e.g. for Header you can create a Header template and save all your header images in Header Template, similarly for Footer you can create another template with naming Footer and save all your Footer images into that Template):

There are two options available for inserting all your images into a single document template

Option A: Drag and drop the image to the Template

  • Save the images into your local drive
  • Drop or Simply Copy & paste the image into the document generation template.
  • Select that particular image and click the additional options (three dots) from the menu.
  • From the menu, choose Insert/edit Image.
  • Copy the Source URL (e.g., data: image/jpeg; base64, XXXXXXXXXXXX) that is generated when an image is dropped.
  • Save the template.

Option B: Insert the link to add image to the template (Preferred Option)

  • Click on the three dots of the editor from the menu.
  • Select Insert/Edit Image

  • Add the image URL (You can raise a ticket with SAP to host the images into SAP/SF Server to generate a URL of the images)

  • Set description (if required) and adjust the dimensions
  • Click Ok and save the template.

Step 2: Create Letter Content and Insert the Image Placeholder in Next/Another New Template:

  • In this template, you can insert your content along with image placeholders.
  • Open another new document template where you want to insert the image
  • Click the additional options (three dots) menu again.
  • Select Insert/Edit Image.
  • Type the placeholder only in Source URL. (For ex. [[Header]])
  • Set the Dimensions

  • Click on OK and Save the template (Once the template saved, URL will auto generate)
  • Post Save, the template will look something like below

Step 3: Write the Business Rule:

  • Go to Configure Business Rule Configuration section & create a rule with a scenario: Document Generation Template Mapping Rule and Select Object 1 as â€œJob Informationâ€

  • Choose your if conditions (based on client requirement) and set your then condition. In Set condition map the copied Source URL (the link generated in Step 1), similar way we can write if else statement.
  • Save the business rule.

Step 4: Assign Rule to Placeholder:

  • Navigate to Manage Document Template Mapping.
  • Search for that particular Document Template created in Step 2
  • Assign the business rule to the corresponding placeholder[[Header]] or [[Footer]] in the template.

 

CONCLUSION:

So, at last, Iâ€™ve been able to deliver dynamic headers and footers to meet customer expectations.

Now â€” what did you think of this post? Were the concepts clear? Iâ€™d love to hear your feedback or questions in the comments.â€

entry.title: SAC seamless planning: Model design principles - compared to SAP BW
entry.content:
After years of developing planning solutions with SAP BW Integrated Planning and BPC, I recently completed a SAC Planning project with seamless planning. Coming from a BW IP/BPC background, I initially tried to replicate familiar structures in SAC. But I quickly realized that SACâ€™s flexibility requires a different mindset, starting with model design and granularity.

In this first blog post, Iâ€™ll share model design decisions, and practical tips for BW developers moving to SAC Planning. This blog post shall also help developers without BW background by highlighting the restrictions of certain functionalities in SAC. Finally, I also want to show you the potential additional value of seamless planning for your planning project.

1. SAC vs. SAP BW modelling: general background information

In SAC, the new model is a mixture of InfoCube-like and a direct-update planning ADSO in BW. All characteristics are keys (InfoCube-like), but there is only an active table (direct-update). Furthermore, measures in SAC models cannot be of a text/characteristic type. So,

  • there are no requests, no chance to roll back
  • no inherited delta mechanism
  • no characteristic as key figure.

But SAC models come with a Standard data audit functionality, that works out of the box (except for import jobs). Because of the missing requests in SAC, planning functions should be kept simple.

2. Model Design: SAC is not BW

When designing planning solutions in SAC, I recommend you to break down planning requirements across multiple models. In SAP BW, developers were required to create composite providers and aggregation levels (and input enabled queries) on top of ADSOs to structure planning logic. SAC does not have those intermediate layers, which can accelerate development. But this simplicity also introduces challenges when trying to consolidate everything into a single model.

Here are a few examples:

  • Any data entry creates an edit version. If multiple planning scenarios share one model, SAC shows the â€œPublish Dataâ€ banner across all stories when you edit plan data in one story.

  • The SAC Excel Add-In allows end users to plan on ad-hoc created tables, which can be convenient for flexibility. However, this becomes significantly more critical when SAC models are large and complex. In such cases, ad-hoc planning can bypass frontend validations (for instance, javascript logic in stories), leading to inconsistencies and governance challenges (check comments here Ability to disable planning option in SAC Cloud excel add-in centrally by admin).
  • Upload jobs in SAC cannot derive master data automatically. In huge models, this often leads to wide files with many columns.
  • Data validations are less robust than characteristic relationships in BW. They must be handled manually in Data Actions and carefully considered during story design, since SAC still allows "unassigned" values even when validations are defined.
  • Data point comments are more fragile. Because they depend on the full navigation state, they can be lost more easily in huge models.

These limitations highlight the need to rethink model design. Instead of treating an SAC planning model like a BW ADSO, itâ€™s more accurate to compare it to an aggregation level or even an input enabled query. It's a layer tailored to specific planning logic.

3. How does seamless planning help?

Seamless planning let's you expose your fact and dimension tables to Datasphere. Hence, you can bring together the data of your different models more easily for reporting purposes instead of having a lot of cross model copies in native SAC.

You can also

  • add SQLscript logic,
  • enrich your plan data with Datasphere tables for configuration/customizing (multiple keys and characteristics as non-key fields),
  • or leveraging public dimensions exposed from SAC (single key).

The results can be consumed

  • via real-time reporting (Datasphere Analytic Models)
  • or via import jobs to SAC models.

4. What's next?

With the Q4/2025 update, seamless planning shall become bidirectional, meaning that the View data in Datasphere can be added to SAC models as read-only version. This update will make Datasphere data better accessible. It will support direct consumption of Datasphere fact data in planning models, which will let you have a single planning enabled table with real-time reference data from other planning models.

Summary

  • Model design matters: Avoid putting all planning scenarios into one model. SAC lacks BWâ€™s aggregation layer, so splitting models improves performance and governance. 
  • Seamless Planning currently focuses on exposing SAC fact and dimension tables to SAP Datasphere, enabling integrated reporting and SQLScript-based logic. It will help you implementing a federated planning landscape in SAC.
  • Always keep the Roadmap in mind: By Q4/2025, SAC will support direct consumption of Datasphere fact data in planning models, reducing reliance on import jobs and enabling real-time integration in planning enabled crosstabs.

entry.title: Re: Experience with UPA
entry.content:
Hi,

I've worked with UPA on a SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud implementation where UPA has been made mandatory by SAP, indicating that it is viewed as a best practice for future implementations. UPA effectively addresses limitations in ledger functionality and the availability of multiple currencies defined in FI configuration across the SAP S/4HANA landscape.

For SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud and On-Premise customers, UPA has been available since the 2022 release, with significant enhancements introduced in the 2023 release. In existing systems, retroactive activation requires a migration process and adherence to stringent prerequisites, which are only supported starting from the 2023 release. Notably, only the US and DE localizations are currently supported.

For new SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud or On-Premise implementations, I strongly recommend a thorough evaluation of UPA activation, keeping in mind the limitations outlined in the 3191636 - Universal Parallel Accounting: Scope Information. 

Best regards,
Jonathan

entry.title: The Power of One: How Unified SAP Joule Boosts AI Adoption (a technical sight)
entry.content:
Short read. Big pictures.

What is â€˜Unified SAP Jouleâ€™? One Joule for all SAP solutions, independent of the underlying tech stacks. (End users know â€˜SAP,â€™ not SFSF/S4/BS, etc.)

Why unify? Better user acceptance â†’ better adoption. If users donâ€™t accept it, they wonâ€™t adopt it.

How to get there? Use the SAP IAM Reference Architecture for SAP Joule as the backbone, following down below:

 

1) Overview

Everything SAPâ€‘labeled shows up to the corporate IAM/IdP as SAP Cloud Identity (SCI). Inside the SAP domain, identities & authorizations are unified so the landscape can be SAPâ€‘managed later. User management, role/group assignment, and authentication all go through SAP Cloud Identity Services.

â€ƒ

2) Common Data Model (CDM)

At design time â€“ when activating SAP Joule, each business solution (e.g., S/4HANA) exposes its Joule capabilities via CDM. Joule functions map to business roles; CDM content is deployed to SAP Build Work Zone (WZ); Roles defined in CDM appear as roles in Content Manager.
E.g. S4 HANA Capability <-> S/4 HANA Business Role <-> CDM role <-> Role in WZ <-> Capability in WZ.
Given that, SAP Joule knows at DT what authorizations a user need for which capability.

 

3) Sync of Authorizations

Roles/groups and identity assignments from business solution (S/4 HANA, SuccessFactors, â€¦) synchronize into Work Zone. Synchronizing groups and assignments into SCI are optional today and may become required if WZ polls SCI. Thirdâ€‘party IAM can assign groups to users via SCI; Work Zoneâ€™s user store is independent of XSUAA.

 

4) Sync of Identities

Identities flow through SCIM to your identity management, centrally governed across SAP. The Global Unique User Identifier is synchronized from SCI into the business solutions.

 

5) Authentication Flow

All authentication goes through SAP Cloud Identity Services (IAS), enabling principal propagation behind the scenes (later more). This is the basis for Unified SAP Joule and prepares the path for SAPâ€‘managed connectivity when new services are subscribed.

 

6) Example: Endâ€‘toâ€‘End Authentication

  1. User opens Joule.
  2. Joule asks IAS to authenticate user; Optional: IAS forwards authentication to Corporate IdP and enriches token with IAS information (GUUID) after authentication (identity federation).
  3. User is authenticated to use Joule while Joule knows, which capabilities the user is allowed to use.
  4. User is calling a Joule capability (e.g. Create leave request).
  5. Joule asks IAS for a token for this specific identity for the business solution of the capability to be called.
  6. IAS is handing out the token.
  7. Joule can authenticate as the user to the business solution (principal propagation).
  8. Joule calling the function module inside the business solution in the name of the user.

This illustrates the importance for all solutions and the BTP within this scenario to trust the same authentication instance (IAS).

 

7) 3rdâ€‘Party Identity Management (where it fits)

  • Identity sources: SFSF (internals), Fieldglass (externals), or AD.
  • Synchronization of users between SFSF and SCI.
  • GUUID is written back to SFSF.
  • Groups originate in SaaS solutions and show as SCI groups can sync to 3rd-party IAM.
  • S/4 HANA roles can sync to 3rdâ€‘party IAM.
  • Management split:
    • BTP & SaaS via SCI.
    • S/4 HANA via IAM directly plus GUUID provisioning:
      • IAM reads from SCI and provisions to S/4 HANA, or
      • SCI reads from S/4 HANA and writes back UserID+GUUID only;
      • Both option align with the reference architecture.

 

Final thought

Unify identity and auth once â†’ unlock Joule everywhere. Less friction. More adoption. Happier users. ðŸŽ¯

entry.title: Consuming Events from SAP Advanced Event Mesh with the Event AddOn for ERP and/or AIFAEM
entry.content:
Introduction

There are multiple ways to connect an SAP Integration Suite, Advanced Event Mesh (AEM) Broker to your S/4HANA or ECC System.

  1. Enterprise Event Enablement (IWXBE) via AMQP --> see this Blog
  2. Event Add On for ERP via REST
  3. Custom REST Service

In this Blog I will shortly introduce you to Approaches 2 and 3. Details can be found in the Github Repository. 

Defining Outbound Events is quite simple. Somewhere in the System an event is happening. The Event Enablement Solution just has to push the Event to the Event Broker, possibly with some additional Data. Defining Inbound Events on the opposite obviously depends on the event payload. If it is a Notification Event which is relevant for this consuming system, an API has to be called to fetch more data to be processed. To make it simple, in this Blog we assume the consumed Event is a Data Event, containing all data required to process the Event. Also in that case the processing of the event highly depends on the event structure. That is why coding is inevitable, regardless of the chosen Event Enablement solution (RAP, Event AddOn for ERP, AIFAEM).

The only way to avoid custom coding in the ECC or S/4HANA System is the consumption of the Event using the AEM Adapter of BTP Integration Suite, Cloud Integration. Here it is possible to map the Event to a Payload which can be processed by a Standard API provided by the ECC / S/4HANA System. 

In this Blog I show you how you can extend the EventAddOn Approach with AIFAEM both for Monitoring & Mapping only or for Monitoring, Mapping and Processing in AIF. Also there is the possibility to create a custom REST Service to pass the message to AIF directly. In both cases the AEM REST Delivery Point (RDP) SetUp is not part of the Blog. If you want to know how to set up a RDP, feel free to check out this Blog. Here we simulate the RDP by API Client Bruno.

 

Event Add On for ERP via REST + AIFAEM

The SAP Event Add-on for ERP is a great Tool, which makes it easy to push custom Events from your ECC or S/4HANA System to SAP Integration Suite, advanced Event Mesh (AEM) based on a low code/no code approach. For the consumption of Events, the AddOn offers a pre delivered SICF Service, where Endpoints for every Inbound Event can be customized. These Endpoints have to be called from a REST Delivery Point on AEM. 

The whole set up (among a lot of other helpful material) is available in this Mission in the SAP Discovery Center.

Additional to the Event Addon I have set up two scenarios which add the AIF component to the Event AddOn. 

1) Mapping and Monitoring in AIF, Processing in IDoc Process Code Function Module

Request:

 

Result in Event AddOn Monitor

Idoc Monitoring

AIF Monitoring

2) Mapping, Monitoring & Processing in AIF Action

Request:

 

Result:

IDoc Monitor

 

AIF Error Monitoring

HowTo and Development Artifacts see here

 

Custom REST Service & AIFAEM

AIFAEM offers the licence Part (all interfaces which are connected with AEM are included in the AEM licence) and Development Artifacts like DDIC Types (Cloud Event Header) and an Action to push Outbound Events to AEM. For Inbound Events there is no pre delivered connector, so it is necessary to create a custom HTTP Handler Class and SICF Node to pass the Events to AIF. I have decided to provide only one endpoint and the interface determination happens based on the Topic Header and a regular expression maintained in an AIF Value Mapping. 

In my Github Repository I provide a class and other configurations you can take over and adapt to your needs.

Request:

Result in AIF Error Monitoring:

 

HowTo and Development Artifacts see here

 

Summary

With SAP Integration Suite, advanced Event Mesh, Cloud Integration, RAP, the Event AddOn for ERP and AIFAEM we have a lot of options, which even can be combined to fit to your requirements and skillset. This Blog shows how the EventAddOn and AIF can be combined or AIFAEM can be used with a custom REST Service.

entry.title: Establishing connectivity between a local CAP runtime and on-premise systems
entry.content:
SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) offers a complete suite of tools and services to access on-premise systems such as SAP S/4HANA, SAP HANA On-Premise, any OData service, generic HTTP services, or any other service supporting the TCP/IP protocol. â€¯The SAP Cloud Application Programming Model (CAP) provides tools and guidance for developing and testing cloud services, prioritizing local development. The challenge of integrating on-premise services with a local CAP application development setup is where CAPâ€™s value truly shines. The following blog serves as a comprehensive guide, outlining detailed steps to integrate these two platforms.

Install and configure the Cloud Connector

To establish a secure connection to on-premise services, it is essential to install the Cloud Connector within your local network environment. Ensure that the target on-premise system is accessible from this network, as the Cloud Connector will facilitate communication between your cloud applications and the on-premise services.

Cloud Connector installation

The Cloud Connector can be installed on variety of operating systems as described here.

Cloud Connector configuration

To facilitate the initial setup of connectivity between SAP BTP and the Cloud Connector, the authentication information has already been prepared. Download the authentication data file from your SAP BTP subbaccount:

  1. open your SAP BTP subaccount in your favourite browser
  2. navigate to "Cloud Connectors"
  3. press the button "Download Authentication Data"

Establish connection between Cloud Connector and your SAP BTP subaccount:

  1. open the Cloud Connector administration panel: https://localhost:8443/
  2. login with the default username and password: Administrator/manage, when prompted change the password following the instructions
  3. choose installation type: Master (Primary Installation) and provide description of your choice
  4. press "Add Subaccount" to connect to yout SAP BTP subaccount
  5. provide the internet proxy configuration if applicable and press "Next"
  6. choose "Configure using authentication data" and press "Next"
  7. choose "Add subaccount authentication data from file"
  8. press "Browse" and provide the previously downloaded authentication data file from your SAP BTP subaccount then press "Next"
  9. in the last dialog fill in the required information of your choice and press "Finish"

Your Cloud Connector is now available to your SAP BTP subaccount.

Let's expose the resources that need to be made visible in your SAP BTP subaccount:

  1. in the Cloud Connector Administration panel navigate to the connected subaccount
  2. choose "Cloud to On-Premise"
  3. in the "Access Control" tab press the Plus "+" button located in the header of the table "Mapping Virtual to Internal System"
  4. choose the type of the system to be exposed. In this guide a CAP OData endpoint will be used - choose "Non-SAP System"
  5. choose the appropriate protocol, in the current example it is "HTTP"
  6. provide internal host and port to expose, for example: "localhost" and "4004" and press "Next"
  7. choose "Allow Principal Propagation" if applicable
  8. select the Principal type, which is "Kerberos" by default
  9. choose which host to provide in the request header
  10. provide a description of your choice
  11. press "Finish"

The exposed host:port combination is now available, in addition resources must be exposed:

  1. in the Cloud Connector Administration panel navigate to the connected subaccount
  2. choose "Cloud to On-Premise"
  3. switch to tab "Access Control" in case it is not already selected by default
  4. in the table "Resources of localhost:4004" press the Plus "+"  to add new resource
  5. provide the URL to expose, for example: "/" - the root path of the web server
  6. choose the "Access Policy", for example ""Path and All Sub-Paths" will allow access to any URL on that server
  7. press "Save"

The configuration is now complete. By checking the 'Cloud Connectors' in the relevant BTP subaccount, you should see the already configured Cloud Connector and the exposed backend system, for example, 'localhost:4004'.

 

CAP Application setup

To access an on-premise backend system, the CAP application must utilize the destination and connectivity services provided by SAP BTP. If you don't already have a CAP application, you can easily set up a new one with the following command:

cds init sample --add sample && cd sample

Enable both destination and connectivity, and also deployment via mta with the following command:

cds add destination,connectivity,xsuaa,mta

Subsequent deployment will automatically create the required BTP instances for the destination and connectivity services.

If you prefer to manually instantiate the destination and connectivity services, you can do so with the following commands:

  • destination service
cf create-service destination lite sample-destination
cf create-service-key sample-destination sample-destination-key
  • connectivity service
cf create-service connectivity lite sample-connectivity
cf create-service-key sample-connectivity sample-connectivity-key

To access the SAP BTP services locally in a hybrid development environment, bind the necessary SAP BTP services. For connectivity, set the proxy host to localhost, as it defaults to an internally accessible SAP BTP hostname (see Overwrite Cloud Service Credentials):

npx cds bind --to sample-connectivity --credentials "{ \"onpremise_proxy_host\": \"localhost\" }"
npx cds bind --to sample-destination
npx cds bind --to sample-auth

Accessing systems via the connectivity service requires a destination with proxy type OnPremise. The destination can be either on subaccount level or instance based and can be created either via mta or manually in the SAP BTP destination service UI by providing the following parameters, where the host:port must be the same as the previously configured Cloud Connector (localhost:4004) :

Name: 'on-prem-dest'
Type: 'HTTP'
Authentication: 'NoAuthentication'
URL: 'http://localhost:4004'
ProxyType: 'OnPremise'
Description: 'on-premise destination'

Destinations can be created alternatively programmatically utilizing the Destination REST API:

  • install the Cloud SDK http client, xsenv and xssec packages required to create the destination
npm i -D "@sap-cloud-sdk/http-client"
npm i -D "@sap/xsenv"
npm i -D "@sap/xssec"
  • create a new file named createNewDestination.js with the following content:
(async () => {
const xsenv = require('@sap/xsenv')
const xssec = require('@sap/xssec')
const destinationCredentials = xsenv.serviceCredentials({ tag: 'destination' })
const xsuaaService = new xssec.XsuaaService(destinationCredentials)
const token = await xsuaaService.fetchClientCredentialsToken()
const { executeHttpRequest } = require('@sap-cloud-sdk/http-client')
const destinationName = 'on-prem-dest'
const data = JSON.stringify({
  Name: destinationName,
  Type: 'HTTP',
  Description: 'on-prem destination',
  URL: 'http://linux:4004',
  ProxyType: 'OnPremise',
  Authentication: 'NoAuthentication'
})
try {
  const response = await executeHttpRequest({
    url: destinationCredentials.uri + "/destination-configuration/v1/instanceDestinations" },{
    method: 'POST',headers: {
    "Authorization": "Bearer " + token.access_token,
    'X-CSRF-Token': 'None'},
    data
  })
  console.log("Create destination", destinationName, response.status, response.statusText)
} catch(e) {
  console.log("Failed to create destination", destinationName, e.status, e.response?.data)
}
})()
  • run the newly created script file with SAP BTP service bindings using the command:
cds bind --exec node createNewDestination.js

In order to use that destination in a CAP application, a new service needs to be defined with the destination specified as parameter. Add the following configuration to your package.json file providing the name of the already created destination:

"cds": {
  "requires": {
    "OnPremService": {
      "kind": "odata",
      "credentials": {
        "destination": "on-prem-dest"
      }
    }
  }
}

The connectivity proxy port should be forwarded to SAP BTP via a ssh tunnel. In order to open a ssh connection to SAP BTP an already deployed microservice is required. In case you do not have one then an initial deployment can be performed via the following command:

cds up

In case there is no current CAP application to deploy, a newly created CAP app can serve that purpose:

cds init sample --add sample,xsuaa && cd sample && npx cds up

Open a ssh tunnel to the SAP BTP microservice with the connectivity proxy port forwarded with the command:

cf ssh sample-srv -L 20003:connectivityproxy.internal.cf.eu12.hana.ondemand.com:20003

The created destination was configured as an HTTP endpoint with port 4004. To test the destination, ensure the CAP service is running locally on port 4004. Start the CAP service with the SAP BTP services bound by executing the following command in the root directory of your CAP project:

PORT=4004 cds bind --exec cds-serve --profile hybrid

Perform an initial destination check via the Destinations UI in SAP BTP by selecting the destination and then pressing the 'Check Destination' button.

 

Setup validation

With the Cloud Connector instance running locally and connected to your SAP BTP subaccount, a reachable SAP BTP destination, the tunneled connectivity proxy, and the locally running CAP service, you can perform the final validation of the setup.

Create a new file named testOnPremSystem.js with the following content. Adapt the service name and resource path in the get method to match your specific case:

  (async () => {
  const cds = require ('@sap/cds')
  const onPremService = await cds.connect.to("OnPremService")
  try {
    let res = await onPremService.get("/odata/v4/test/OnPremService")
    console.log(res)
  } catch(e) {
    console.log(e)
  }
  })()

Run the test with service bindings:

cds bind --exec node testOnPremService.js

With everything configured and running, the CAP application can be extended with functionality to access an on-premise system.

An already preconfigured and functional example containing scripts to ease the validation of the scenario is available on github in the following repository: github: on-prem-connectivity-example .

entry.title: SAP BTP Developer's Guide: Extending Fiori Elements with the Flexible Programming Model
entry.content:
Are you leveraging the full potential of SAP Fiori Elements' Flexible Programming Model in your enterprise applications? While this powerful capability has been available for sometime now, many developers are still discovering how to effectively implement its extension points, building blocks, and controller extensions to solve real-world business requirements.

If you've been curious about extending your Fiori elements applications beyond standard floorplans but weren't sure where to start, the SAP BTP Developer's Guide offers a comprehensive learning path that covers this and much more.
 

What is the Flexible Programming Model ?

 

The Flexible Programming Model offers an extensive toolkit for extending Fiori elements applications beyond standard floorplans. It provides multiple ways to customize and enhance your applications while maintaining enterprise standards and framework compliance.
The Flexible Programming Model encompasses four main areas:
  • Extension Points: including custom sections, actions, columns, header facets, dialogs, form elements, filters, pages, views, and KPI tags.
  • Building Blocks: reusable fields such as forms, tables, charts, filter bars, and specialized controls that maintain framework compliance. These are consistently orchestrated by the framework, ensuring you automatically benefit from SAP Fiori compliance and standard application behavior like draft handling and side effects.
  • Controller Extensions: for customizing edit flows, state handling, routing, navigation, and message handling - allowing you to override specific methods to enable more flexibility while preserving framework functionality.
  • SAP Fiori Elements Advanced Features: including sophisticated capabilities like Side Effects for dynamic UI behavior, UI.Hidden annotations for conditional visibility, UI.PartOfPreview annotations for optimized data loading, and enhanced Value Help configurations for improved user experience.
When using the Flexible Programming Model to extend your Fiori elements applications, you automatically preserve all the enterprise-ready features that SAP Fiori Elements provides out of the box:
  • Accessibility
  • Internationalization
  • Mobile Compatibility
  • Performance Optimizations
  • Integration
  • Security
  • Lifecycle Stability
  • Test Automation Support
  • UX Consistency
  • and much more ...
The key advantage is that the Flexible Programming Model allows you to add custom functionality while maintaining all these enterprise features that would otherwise require significant manual implementation and ongoing maintenance in freestyle development.

Complementary Development Approaches

 

The SAP BTP Developer's Guide provides clear recommendations for building Fiori applications that balance rapid development with flexibility needs. Rather than viewing these as competing alternatives, the guide positions them as complementary approaches that work together to deliver consistent, enterprise-grade solutions.
 
 
Use SAP Fiori elements for OData V4 to benefit from a presentation of a common UI and UX. This approach provides the foundation for rapid development while ensuring consistency across your application portfolio. Personalization and theming are automatically supported, giving users the flexibility they need without additional development effort.

For more flexibility, use SAP Fiori element's Flexible Programming Model with or without SAPUI5 Freestyle. This approach allows you to extend beyond standard capabilities while maintaining the benefits of the Fiori elements framework. The Flexible Programming Model serves as the bridge between standard floorplans and complete customization.

SAP Fiori elements and SAPUI5 help you present one consistent solution experience to your customers, and you benefit from the upcoming designs and UX improvements automatically. This means your applications evolve with the platform without requiring manual updates to maintain modern standards.

Important consideration: Remember that even the simplest UI components or more complex ones like geographic maps have compliance requirements like accessibility and theming. When extending beyond standard Fiori elements capabilities, these requirements must be carefully maintained to ensure enterprise-grade applications.
 

Enterprise-Grade Development on SAP BTP

 

The SAP BTP Developer's Guide serves as the comprehensive starting point for developing business applications on SAP Business Technology Platform. It provides essential recommendations and best practices that help developers navigate the complexities of enterprise application development.
 
Within this guide, the mission Develop an Enterprise-Grade CAP Application Following the SAP BTP Developer's Guide offers hands-on experience with critical enterprise development topics, including Change Tracking, Audit Logging, Attachments, Freestyle SAPUI5, Flexible Programming model and more.
 
While the mission covers multiple enterprise development aspects, the Flexible Programming Model section provides particularly valuable insights for developers looking to extend Fiori elements applications.
 
The learning scenarios are built around the Incident Management application, a practical business application where organizations can maintain and track incidents on behalf of their customers. This application already features a complete UI based on the SAP Fiori elements List Report Page floorplan, providing the perfect foundation to demonstrate how the Flexible Programming Model can enhance existing standard implementations.
The mission showcases several key extension capabilities that go beyond standard Fiori elements floorplans:
 
Extension Points: Custom Column
Learn to extend the Incidents table in the List Report Page with a custom column. This custom column demonstrates the integration of the MicroProcessFlow control, allowing processors to track incident progress directly within the table view.
 
 
Extension Points: Custom Header Facet
Discover how to enhance the header section in the Object Page by adding a custom header facet. This implementation showcases the MicroProcessFlow control in the header area, providing processors with immediate visibility into incident progress.
 
 
Extension Points: Custom Action
Implement a custom Location action in the Object Page that demonstrates practical integration of the GeoMap control. This custom action opens a dialog displaying customer locations, showing how to integrate specialized controls for business-specific functionality.
 
 
Extension Points: Custom Section
Add a comprehensive Process Flow custom section to the Object Page. This section demonstrates the implementation of the ProcessFlow control, providing detailed visualization of incident workflows and status transitions.
 
 
Controller Extension
Learn to extend the Fiori Elements Object Page controller to customize standard behaviors. This section demonstrates how to override the edit flow while maintaining framework compliance and enterprise standards.
 
 

Conclusion

The mission Develop an Enterprise-Grade CAP Application Following the SAP BTP Developer's Guide provides a comprehensive learning experience that goes beyond traditional tutorials. By combining Flexible Programming Model techniques with other essential enterprise development skills, you'll be equipped to build applications that meet real-world business requirements while maintaining the highest standards of enterprise software development.

Whether you're looking to extend existing Fiori elements applications or planning new enterprise solutions, this mission offers the practical, hands-on experience you need to master the art of enterprise application development on SAP BTP.
 
Happy Learning !

entry.title: How to integrate SAP Signavio with SAP Cloud ALM, tenant extension
entry.content:
We are pleased to announce that support for the standard integration of SAP Signavio and SAP Cloud ALM has been extended to the SAP Cloud ALM, tenant extension, allowing to integrate SAP Signavio with additionally purchased SAP Cloud ALM systems.

In case you are not familiar with the current integration approach, I highly recommend our previous blog post.

The integration setup of SAP Signavio with SAP Cloud ALM, tenant extension consists of two steps:

  • Provisioning the connectivity add-on for SAP Signavio solutions, which connects to your SAP Signavio workspace
  • Establishing the integration to your SAP Cloud ALM, tenant extension

Please note, that an SAP Signavio workspace can still be only connected to a single SAP Cloud ALM tenant. Also, the SAP Cloud ALM tenant still needs to belong to the same CRM customer as the SAP Signavio workspace.

Step 1 â€“ Provision the connectivity add-on for SAP Signavio solutions

First, youâ€™ll need to provision the connectivity add-on for SAP Signavio solutions in SAP for Me. If you have already completed this step, please continue with step two.

  • To start, enter the SAP for Me Systems & Provisioning page.
    In the section of SAP Systems > Systems to be Provisioned you can find the option to trigger the provisioning for each SAP Signavio workspace you own:

  • After selecting the Start Provisioning option, a dialog will appear to customize the provisioning details.
  • Select and confirm the SAP Cloud Identity Service and the SAP Signavio System and select Submit.
    Please note, that your SAP Cloud ALM, tenant extension system wonâ€™t appear here. Therefore, do not select any SAP Cloud ALM system.
  • After submitting the request, you can track the progress in the Provisioning Status table:
  • As soon as the status is reported as Provided, you can continue with the next step.

Step 2 â€“ Set up the Integration with your SAP Cloud ALM tenant

To complete the integration, youâ€™ll need to enter the BTP Global Account of your SAP Cloud ALM tenant.

  • Launch the BTP Cockpit and navigate to your SAP Cloud ALM Global Account. See Finding Your Systems on SAP for Me for more details on how to navigate there. navigate there.
  • In the left navigation bar, open the System Landscape > Formations view.
  • Select Create Formation and enter the following details:
    • Enter a Formation Name, e.g. Signavio Cloud ALM Integration
    • Select the following Formation Type: Integration with SAP Signavio and SAP Cloud ALM
  • Confirm by selecting Next Step.
  • On the next screen, select your connectivity add-on for SAP Signavio solutions and SAP Cloud ALM systems. Here, you will now also see your SAP Cloud ALM, tenant extension system.
  • Navigate to the last screen to confirm the configuration by selecting Create.
  • Once the status of your formation is reported as Ready, the integration has been completed.

Leverage the Sync to SAP Cloud ALM from your SAP Signavio workspace

Once the setup is completed, you can open a BPMN diagram in the SAP Signavio Process Collaboration Hub â€“ Preview Mode to sync it to your SAP Cloud ALM system.

For more details about syncing BPMN diagrams, please refer to Manually Syncing BPMN Diagrams to SAP Cloud ALM.

Additional References

Learn more about the standard integration of SAP Signavio with SAP Cloud ALM

SAP Help - Provision the connectivity add-on for SAP Signavio solutions

SAP Help - Manually Syncing BPMN Diagrams to SAP Cloud ALM

SAP Note - How to integrate SAP Signavio and SAP Cloud ALM after provisioning the connectivity add-on for SAP Signavio solutions

SAP Note - How to Start Provisioning for a cloud product - SAP for Me

entry.title: Re: When lowercase letters are entered as input in CONVER...
entry.content:
Hello @SKBS_ITO 

The CONVERSION_EXIT_CUNIT_INPUT function does two attempts - the 1st one with input as provided (with lowercase letters), the 2nd one with input translated to uppercase:

  PERFORM conversion_exit_cunit_input                       "*058i+
          USING    input
                   language
          CHANGING output
                   lv_unit_found.
  IF lv_unit_found IS INITIAL.
* If the unit was not found this can be due to the
* fact that the letters that are maintained as capital
* letters were entered as lower case letters. In this case
* translate to upper case and repeat.
    lv_input = input.
*    PERFORM trans_latin_to_upper_case                      "*067d+
*            CHANGING lv_input.
    PERFORM trans_to_upper_case                             "*067i
            CHANGING lv_input.                              "*067i
    PERFORM conversion_exit_cunit_input
            USING    lv_input
                     language
            CHANGING output
                     lv_unit_found.
    IF lv_unit_found IS INITIAL.
    OUTPUT = INPUT.
    HELP = INPUT.     " falls an INPUT ein Konvertierungsexit haengt
    MESSAGE E305 WITH HELP LANGUAGE RAISING UNIT_NOT_FOUND.
  ENDIF.
  ENDIF.                                                    "*058i-

Best regards

Dominik Tylczynski

entry.title: Reducing Change Orders Through Data-Driven Procurement on SAP Business Network
entry.content:
Change Order Rate measures the percentage of purchase orders issued by buyers that have a subsequent change. Change orders are often the result of poor practices on the buy-side including the following:

  • Incorrect pricing or quantities on original purchase orders
  • Over issuance of blankets
  • Missing information on purchase order (e.g., missing buyer tax identification ID, incorrect shipping address, incorrect contact name, etc.)
  • Missing or incorrect catalogue or contract data.

Changer orders increase operational costs of small and large suppliers alike. Whereas new purchase orders may be automatically integrated to a supplier's order fulfillment system, most change orders are manually processed or result high touch exception processing after automated receipt.

Change order rate on SAP Business Network

SAP Business Network publishes KPIs and benchmarks related to transaction performance including:

  • Change order rate
  • Invoice exception rate
  • Invoice cycle time
  • On time payment rate
  • Days paid late
  • Days to pay

Network benchmarking provide aggregate across all suppliers on SAP Business Network (SBN), allowing supplier to compare their customer specific performance (KPIs) against industry averages and identify opportunities for improvement, cost reduction, or risk mitigation. 

As a former Price Waterhouse consultant, we used to say to our clients that â€œwhat gets measured gets doneâ€.  Such is the case when it comes to network benchmarks. Since SBN first began publishing the overall trend for PO change rate has reduced from a peak of 58% in December 2024 to 44% in September 2025.

The publishing of change order rate metrics has inspired internal and external initiatives focused on increasing catalogue orders.

Catalogues ensure that the items, descriptions, part numbers, and unit prices used in purchase orders (POs) are consistent and pre-approved.

  • Without catalogues: Buyers often create free-text POs or reference outdated price lists, which can lead to mismatched prices or obsolete items â€” resulting in change orders to correct them.
  • With catalogues: Buyers select from controlled, up-to-date items, eliminating the need for suppliers to issue change orders to correct pricing or product details.

Platinum suppliers on SAP Business Network can quicky monitor catalogue trends using Analytics on Purchase Order Items and selecting catalogue or non-catalogue in the filter criteria.  Catalogue performance can be measured by order count or order amount.

Conclusion

By leveraging network analytics and driving the adoption of catalog-based purchasing, suppliers can significantly reduce change orders, streamline operations, and strengthen collaboration with customers across the SAP Business Network.

entry.title: SAP DM: Synchronizing Production Processes Service Registry Keys (SRKs) Across Landscapes
entry.content:
If you manage Production Processes (PPs) across Development and Production in SAP Digital Manufacturing, you may have seen processes that look identical by name but behave differently between landscapes. The culprit is usually mismatched Service Registry Keys (SRKs). The Service Registry Key (SRK) refer to the URL/Path of the registered PP service in the Manage Service Registry app. Before Release 2505, transports did not include this identifier, so PPs retained their names but received new SRKs when moved. That drift broke references such as POD mappings and introduced ongoing manual effort. Release 2505 changes the game by keeping SRKs consistent during transports, preventing cross-landscape misalignment going forward. This post explains what changed, why it matters, and how to harmonize existing designs created before 2505.

 

Why IDs and SRKs Matter

A Production Process Design (PPD) contains one or multiple PPs. Each PP, once published to Service Registry, has three core properties: Name, ID, and Service Registry Key (SRK). Names are human-friendly; IDs and SRKs are what assignments and references use under the hood. When those technical identifiers differ between landscapes, transports and mappings can point to the wrong target.

 

What Changed in Release 2505

Starting with release 2505, SRKs are exported and imported with the PP. That means transporting a PP preserves its identity across Development and Production. The result is aligned landscapes where assignmentsâ€”such as POD mappingsâ€”continue to reference the correct SRK without manual adjustments.

However, SRKs that are already misaligned between the landscapes will not be realigned automatically. This is because you may already have adjusted calls in Productive and Development landscapes. When the standard would enforce alignment, those implementations would break.

 

The Pre-2505 Problem: Identity Drift Between Landscapes

Before 2505, transports kept PP names and IDs but regenerated SRKs in the target landscape. Over time, Development and Production diverged: the same-named PP in Development could carry a different technical identifier than its counterpart in Production. For example, Production Process 4 in Production might be cleanly defined as ID: PP-4, URL: PP-4.com. In Development, the same process created and transported earlier might instead show up as ID: PP-4, URL: PP-D.com. Transporting more processesâ€”say, Production Process 3 and 4â€”only deepened the differences. Even though names and IDs looked consistent, references and assignments between landscapes pointed to different SRKs, leading to inconsistencies and manual rework.

 

 

 

The Goal: One Identity Across All Landscapes

To fully benefit from Release 2505, existing PPs must be aligned so Name, ID, and SRK match between landscapes. Once aligned, future transports will preserve SRKs automatically, and PP assignments inside PODs will run consistently without manual fixes.

 

Prerequisite

Ensure there are no new or uncommitted developments in the Development Tenant. They will be overwritten during synchronization.

Warning: This implementation approach will replace the SRKs in your Development Tenant. This means if you decide to spend the effort on synchronization, you will not only need to perform the synchronization steps but also adjust all callers to the published production processes in the Development Tenant afterwards. That is why we recommend synchronizing from Production to Development and not the other way around. This way, if you miss one caller, only your Development Tenant has the issue, not the Productive Tenant.

 

Recommended Synchronization Approach

Treat Production as the leading landscape and promote its PP identities to Development. Use the import and export functions for this one-time alignment rather than Cloud Transport Management (CTMS). That way you donâ€™t need to configure new directions for a one-time effort.

 

Step-by-Step Procedure

  1. In Development, create a new version of your PPD.
  2. In that new version, delete all existing PPs.
  3. Add a temporary placeholder PP with a different name and deploy the PPD. This ensures the â€œoldâ€  SRKs are â€œforgottenâ€ by the Development Tenant.
  4. In Production, export the corresponding PPD that contains the correct identities.
  5. Import the exported PPD into Development.
  6. The PPD in Development is overwritten, matching Productionâ€™s SRKs. Deploy the new PPD.
  7. Deploy the synchronized PPs and validate your key assignments.
  8. Update all callers to the new SRKs. This could be POD buttons, external calls from machine integrations, etc.

 

 

 

Operational Tips

- Plan the alignment outside the DM releases.

- Key consideration is the size of your implementation so in other words how many production processes have you created & transported before 2505 and the number of external calls to these processes, as you will need to adjust them in the Development Tenant. On the other hand, you will not need to adjust the callers anymore when moving them between tenants. So you will need to consider the pros and cons of synchronization.

- Treat Production as the source of truth for PP identities when performing the one-time sync.

- After aligning, perform a validation: That PODs and other configurations in your Development Tenant still work. If not, you might have forgotten to update the SRKs to call the PPs behind

- Use import/export for this alignment; reserve CTMS for regular transport post-alignment once identities are consistent.

 

Conclusion

Release 2505 ensures SRKs are preserved during PPD transport, keeping landscapes in sync going forward. To fully unlock those benefits, perform a one-time alignment of pre-2505 PPs by promoting identities from Production to Development. Once done, your transports and POD assignments will remain consistent between landscapes without manual adjustments.

 


We hope this helps your implementation as well!

Dominik, Lukas and Isabelle
